Edit: New reloaded wallet! Way more curves and fillets to help break those sharp edges! Please print a post some pictures! This is a wallet I designed based off a few wallets I have seen on kickstarter. I loved a few features from several of them (the quick access slot from Dash wallet for example), but none of them had all of it so I designed my own. This wallet features
  • Quick access slot for a credit/debit/card you swipe
  • Secure slot for your remaining cards (large amounts if you want to)
  • A place for cash
  • All in the footprint of a credit card
    The only thing you need is 2 hair bands. They work best since they slide well and are the perfect size.
    Note: To get to middle cards slide top hair band down and then it opens better

• Print one of each of the reloaded parts (1,2, and 3)
  • Place quick draw piece on table with lip up
  • Place middle piece (one with the 3 holes in it) on top with lip up
  • Place final piece on top with lip down
  • Place hair bands on and use!
    Note: To get to middle cards slide top hair band down and then it opens better

comments.text: Do you have a heated bed or do you print on something like blue tape? If you do have a heated bed turn up the temp a little bit, and if you use blue tape or similar add so circles on the corners to help the print adhere to the bed. Asteroid models for three bodies, Castalia, Kleopatra and Geographos based on radar and optical data. Model reconstruction is based on digital models developed by Scott Hudson of Washington State University (http://users.tricity.wsu.edu/~hudson/Research/Asteroids/models.html. Note the models are NOT in scale relative to each other (Castalia is 1.8 X .75 km, Geographos 5.1 x 1.8 km, and Kleopatra 217 x 81 km). The stls were sized to give reasonable size models buildable without support structures given their strange shapes.

Files were translated from .obj format to .stls using Rhino3d v4.0 and printed on a Makerbot using white ABS.  The clearish discolored areas seen inthe phots are from leaving them a bit too long in acetone (45 seconds) which I did to smooth out some of the threadiness near the base.

description.text:
My mother purchased an EcoSphere just before Christmas.  An EcoSphere is a self sustaining mini environment containing shrimp, green algae, coral & decorative rocks.  The sphere is supposed to last for anywhere between 5-15 years.  When it arrived my mother asked me to design and print a stand for it.  I refined the design over a few weekends and completed printing it this morning.  I chose to print it in the brand new Taulman 618 Nylon because it could be dyed in any color she wanted, she chose orange.  The stand is completely hollow consisting of only 4 perimeters, the EcoSphere is held in place with some poster tack.  
I have included the Pro/Engineer CAD data for those interested in modifying this design.

• Print Stand without infill, top or bottom. I suggest printing the stand with no more than four perimeters.

  • Stick three small beads of poster tack on the EcoSphere mounting surface.

  • Place EcoSphere on top of stand and enjoy.

title: Mini Modular Framing System - Corner Block and Rail

description.text:
I wanted to make an enclosure for my desktop 3D scanner/turntable, so I don't have to turn the light off every time I want to scan something.
I managed to get some 3mm perspex covered in black vinyl, some at 400mm x 300mm and some at 300mm x 300mm. With these panels in hand, I thought maybe I can print some corner blocks and straight rails to join the panels together to form a black cover over my scanner/turntable. The key thing I have to achieve is to make sure no light is allowed into the box, so they have to join perfectly without any gaps.

Corner.stl - 3 way corner block
100 Straight.stl - rail at 100mm long for joining the straight edges.

comments.text: I love this idea, but I needed it to fit my size of acrylic sheets for a light box.  I recreated it in OpenSCAD and posted it up for use in the Customizer.  I noted your original measurements in the comments for each parameter.  Thank you so much for your work on this!

Frame to hold the extruder controller board and the relay board that attaches the the plastruder MK5 frame.

You'll need 4, 22mm bolts and 2 of the shorter bolts.  Print the frame, shave off a bit of the left bottom and left top feet to make sure they don't rub against the motor bearing.  You'll need to clean out the 6 bolt holes in the frame (use the small allen wrench from the plastruder MK5 kit).  I'd recommend screwing a bolt into each of the 6 holes and then backing them back out (this taps the holes and they will be much easier to screw back in).  Place the frame on the plastruder MK5 (see image). Screw on the bottom two bolts using 22mm bolts.  Put the extruder controller board and the relay board in place.  Screw in the middle two bolts (22mm) and the top two bolts (the shorter ones).
This thing was made with Tinkercad. You can order one here: http://www.shapeways.com/shops/bitforge

It is very important to use fresh, cold water, and freshly ground espresso roast coffee.  A lighter roast will not do.  Kona coffee is not even acceptable for drip.  Heat your portafilter and shot glasses prior to pulling the shots and tamp the coffee into a "puck" with 30 pounds of pressure.

Topographical map of mount everest, using data from the NASA SRTM (shuttle radar topography mission).  Approximately 15 miles square.

I haven't done much tweaking on this, but I printed at .27mm layer height with 3 shells and sparse infill (I think 5%) and got decent results. A smaller layer height would probably look better, and more shells should keep flat areas from forming gaps where they recede too far from the previous layer. And if anyone has a good method for preventing the small blobs from forming on the mountain peaks, I'm all ears. And speaking of ears, the large flat base is prone to warping, so adding some ears to the corners should help prevent that: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:38272

author: teckboss3000

title: Boarding step insert for '59 Glastron Fireflite

description.text:
After 55 years the rubber inserts for the boarding steps on my powerboat are severely perished, shrunken and hardened. I tried to take a mold from one of the old ones several years ago when I first restored the boat, but couldn't get a decent impression. Now that I have the capability to print one, I'm trying again with a computer-generated mold.
I plan to fill the mold with this modified silicone: http://www.google.com/url?sa=t&rct=j&q=&esrc=s&source=web&cd=1&cad=rja&uact=8&sqi=2&ved=0CB0QFjAA&url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.instructables.com%2Fid%2FHow-To-Make-Your-Own-Sugru-Substitute%2F&ei=7rfRU4WCMMewyATIi4DgCg&usg=AFQjCNEmTLURA8qrD3Yj4L-MZleQdqUwPA&bvm=bv.71667212,d.aWw
Stay tuned... .

Printed the female mold, sprayed it lightly with "Pam," and used a goodly amount of pressure with a putty knife to force the "oogoo" into the mold. After four hours, I was able to pull the result from the mold: It worked wonderfully!
I may modify my SCAD code slightly to make the insert a bit "proud" of the frame, but this it definitely serviceable!
All I had on hand was clear silicone caulk, made whitish be the admixture of corn starch. For the final version I'll pick up some white caulk.

comments.text: Update: 30 days later I've found that the casting has shrunk by roughly 1/8-in (about 6mm) in both width and height.  I may modify the design to take this into account, though it would mean letting the casting "age" for awhile before installing.  Also, my son noticed that the plain silicone casting is so flexible that you can pull it out of the frame.  I'm considering printing a scaled sacrificial positive that would be sealed inside the casting to provide x-y rigidity... might want to subtract holes in it to ensure that the finished product is a good, solid unit.  Pondering... pondering... .
comments.author: GA_3D

A da Vinci Style Catapult reproduced by 3D printing technology.
Every parts can be printed without support.
Refer to Leonardo's Machines: Secrets & Inventions in the Da Vinci Codices by Mario Taddei, Domenico Laurenza), Edoardo Zanon
My blog: http://wakalics.blogspot.kr/
Youtube Link: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Gj7cbOEd24M&list=UUO-bsUJqu_i_O71Kg39OlBg

Parts to print:
x1 Base.stl
x1 Spring.stl
x1 Drum.stl
x1 Spoon.stl
x1 Spacer.stl
Vitamin:
A rod of diameter 2.5mm(0.1 inch)
String
Step by step guide:
  • Bond the base and Spring. The holes must concentered. Refer 3rd photo.
  • Put the end of the spoon into the square hole of drum. The open face of spoon must be perpendicular to the circular hole of the drum.
  • Penetrate the base, drum and spacer by rod. Cut the rod into appropriate length
  • Pass through the string into the hole at the middle of the drum. Wind the string to the drum and tie each end to the spring.
  • Enjoy throwing things!

description.text: The pieces were simplified using Meshlab and the "Quadric Edge Collapse Decimation" Filter. The King and Pawn were scaled to fit the other pieces. Netfabb fixed some manifold-errors I was getting.

MeshLab (FOSS on Sourceforge) can be very useful for the simplification of complex geometries without losing the details.
Filters > Remeshing, Simplification and Reconstruction > Quadric Edge Collapse Decimation
These Files were simplified to 10% (0.1 Percentage reduction) of the original Vertex count. File size for the Knight went from 165 MB to 3.2 MB.
Errors in the geometry were then fixed in Netfabb Studio Basic.

description.text: This personal shout-out is meant to adorn your 3D printer. There is a dig-out on the backside to accept the M6 hex heads found all over my Rep2 printer. Attach it at top, bottom, left or right - which ever works best for you. "Always Be Printing"

title: 3D Printed da Vinci Style Movement Converting Device

description.text:
A da Vinci Style Movement Converting Device reproduced by 3D printing technology.
Refer to Leonardo's Machines: Secrets & Inventions in the Da Vinci Codices by Mario Taddei (Editor), Domenico Laurenza (Author), Edoardo Zanon
My blog: http://wakalics.blogspot.kr/
Youtube Link: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GdMQgmJyh3w&list=UUO-bsUJqu_i_O71Kg39OlBg

Parts to print
x2 Large Gear.stl
x2 One Way Gear.stl
x2 One Way Spring.stl
x1 Large Gear Axle.stl
x1 Large Gear Mount.stl
x1 Large Gear Mount left.stl
x1 Small Gear Mount.stl
x1 Small Gear.stl
x1 Small Gear Axle.stl
x1 Pully.stl Step by step guide:
  • Place the One Way Spring into the One Way Gear. Projected cylinder goes into the circular hole of one way gear.
  • Bond Large Gear on the One Way Gear with cyanoacrylate. Make sure these gears remain homocentricity.
  • Make one more.
  • Glue Large Gear Mount, Large Gear Mount left, Small Gear Mount. Refer 6th photo.
  • Bond Small Gear and Small Gear Axle. The square hole of small gear will fit to the square pillar of small gear axle.
  • Put the Small Gear Axle through the hole of Small Gear Mount. Glue the Pully at the end of the Small Gear Axle.
  • Place the Large Gears on the both side of the Large Gear Mount.
  • Penetrate the square holes of Large Gears by Large Gear Axle. Lock the axle and gear with cyanoacrylate.

After looking at a lot of spool holders, and realizing that most would not fit a 2.3 Kg spool, or could not be printed on a Prusa, I decided to design my own. This was the first part I designed and printed.
This configuration has the advantages of never rubbing on the top bars. Allows very fast replacement of spools.

Print one _end and one middle.
The end part requires the top bars to  be  a bit longer than necessary. Remove the two outside nuts, slide on the _end and re-tighten the nuts. The _middle is fastened with zip-ties.
Four 608 bearing on 8 mm rods hold the spool. By adjusting the nuts, different width spools can be accommodated.

This is a fixture I made to match Primo EM172 electret condenser microphone capsules for sensitivity. The speaker is driven by a pink noise signal and the mic capsule under test is recorded in Audacity, then a sample of the recording is analyzed for the rms level.
The mic capsules will be used to make a binaural mic to feed my Sony PCM-M10 digital recorder and some other peoples' projects at the Milwaukee Makerspace.

I designed in DesignSpark Mechanical which allows very easy editing to fit whatever speaker and mic capsules you are using.
I printed with Coex3D Aqua ABS filament on MegaMax with 0.25mm first layer, then 0.2mm layers. Infill was 20%, no support material and no brim required - the pieces shown are right off the print bed with no clean-up or other messing around. The top and bottom pieces fit together tightly.
This allows the Replicator 2X to print PLA. By sliding the filament through a sponge dabbed with oil, the PLA filament doesn't stick to the extruder heater tube.

1: Cut a small strip from a dense sponge and put it in the larger piece.
2: Put on several drops of oil.
3: Slide the PLA filament through both pieces.
4: Push the small piece into the large piece and twist counter-clockwise to lock it in place.
Abstract low-poly numbers to go along with a clock holder in the middle.

remixed_from.author: jonaskuehling
remixed_from.title: Greg's Wade reloaded - Guidler, Tilt Screws, Fishbone Gears

description.text:
A few things annoyed me when I built a new Extruder, so this project started to be just a few fixes but then I ended up fixing a lot of small issues. This is just one more in a long line of extruders derived one from the other. I named it AJGW to reflect contributors in the main line, but I did add all interesting accessories like the heringbone gears and fast release lever. Here are some of the new features: ) new concept split filament guide, fixes better and allows easier access.
) Idler hinge doesn't touch the gear anymore.
) option (default) to use 5/32" screw for the idler which is easy to find
) longer oblong hole for the motor screws. This eliminates the need to remove the motor when testing or adjusting the heringbone gears.
) Top access to screws with ball end allen wrench. This allows for much easier attaching and removing, specially when there is a fan duct. Optional without nut fitting in base.
) Heringbone gears a little thiner and nicer looking. Better fit of the screw
) Open access to the insides for cleaning and inspection, just like Greg's
) Redesigned Fast Release Lever but keeping the same concept
) reinforcement to the upper idler screw attaching point, this was a frequent point of breakage
) reinforcement behind the tractor screw's bearing, to avoid frequent breakage
) reinforcement on the top with a little extra height
) Idler printing sideways, this avoids weakness in the hinge screw
) thicker motor mounting base so that M3x10 screws can be used without extra spacers
) Various external support structures, prints better without automatic support and it is easy to clean.
) Parametric, various simplified optins including 1.75 filament
) Many small things that you will not even notice that they aren't there anymore to annoy you... All metric screws, except for the long idler screws that are not available as metric. A few extras are included, like washers that you can print instead of going out to buy them. It was originaly thought to be used for 0.25mm layers, but it has been tested by some friends with 0.4mm too. I am releasing a few options that make sense to me and to some friends. If you need a different option and are having trouble with the .scad files, please post a comment and I will be glad to include other options. 2013/feb/17: there is an adapter for the Prusa i3 here http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:29795 please let me know if it works! 2013/mar/17: I found another nice support here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:57668 Version 1.1: small reinforcement in the Idler, included STL files for both 4mm and 3/32" (very usefull only in Brazil)

This thing needs a well calibrated 3D printer, but not a high precision one. Please see Slicer parameter at the end of these instructions.
Be carefull not to use Brim for the big gear and washers.
Some parts have optimizations for layer height/width, please check the files names carefully After printing all parts, clean the brim and all support material. === List of printed parts: 1 Extruder body
1 Idler
1 big gear
1 small gear
n M8 washers, stl for 1.2 and 2 mm are included
2 4mm (5/32") washer, to be inserted between the screw and the spring. === BOM, vitamins needed: 3pc 608 bearing
1pc 8mm axis for the idler, length=19mm (or 5/16")
1pc M8 tractor screw
2pc M8 nuts
3pc M3x10 screw for the motor
1pc M3x8 set screw for small gear
1pc M3 nut
3pc M3 washer
2pc screw 5/32 x 2 1/2" this is 62mm long (or optional: M4x60)
2pc nut 5/32" (or optional: 4mm)
2pc M4x 25 hex screw for fixing the base, YMMV
2pc M4 nuts
4pc M4 washers
2ps cloth peg springs, these are cheap and just perfect for the idler
1pc Nema 17 stepper... === Adjustements: The most important adjustmaent is the aligment of the heringbone gears or they will wear out very fast. The EXTERNAL SURFACE of both gears have to be even for correct operations, beware that the small gear is bigger on the inside to allow for some printing variations. The motor should be fixed so that there is no slash but WITHOUT PRESSING the gears toghether. Adjust with filament inserted and springs tensioned fo avoid surprises.

from Slic3r 0.9.7 up there are no (big) fill problems
But this has generaly been optimized for these parameters
Print Idler first to see if all goes well
Allways use RepetierHost to check if Gcode is ok !!! File extensions:
.stl no optimization for layer height/width
.25.stl for printing with 0.25 layer height
.40.stl for printing with 0.40 layer height
.2550.stl .25 layer height, but width must be 0.50 (see bellow)
.4060.stl .40 layer height, but width must be 0.60 (see bellow)
.scad files is not dependant on layers height
gears should allways be 0.25 height, but can be 0.4 on a good printer
NOTE: all parts have their own built-in support (except one idler file) Print settings > Layers and perimeters Perimeter (minimum) = 2 Generate extra perimeters= NO Print settings > Skirt and brim Don't use BRIM for big-gear and washers!!! Brim essencial for Idler, recomended for the rest ==>> For 0.25mm layers:
Print settings > Layers and perimeters
Layer height = 0.25 mm
Horizontal shells, Solid layers = 4 (aprox 1mm)
Print settings > Advanced > Extrusion width
Default extrusion width = 0.50 mm
First layer = 0.48 mm
Perimeters = 0.48 mm
Infill = 0.48 mm
==>> For 0.40mm layers:
Print settings > Layers and perimeters
Layer height = 0.40 mm
Horizontal shells, Solid layers = 3
Print settings > Advanced > Extrusion width
Default extrusion width = 0.60 mm
First layer = 0.58 mm
Perimeters = 0.58 mm
Infill = 0.58 mm
There is some rounding problems and 0.48 or 0.58 allows for better thin walls

Book shelf shaped -small book end for pocket books.
Inspired by Fx-3D design available on shapeways

A derivative, maintaining the assembly procedure, but hopefully improving the aerodynamics.
Includes a drop-in replacement, in which the wing profile is swept to make a smoother surface.
The other part is much larger and based on   a NACA 2818 profile, which should apparently improve power. The arms are a much narrower oval shape to reduce drag.

The NACA2818 profile includes holes for extra stability. Either a long wire can be passed the entire length of one blade, or short dowels can ensure a good fit. The rear edge should obviously be much sharper, but this was creating prints with a disconnected rear edge.
The pegs visible in the photo were meant to allow interlocking between layers. This would require two sets of parts, as there is a 30Â° "shift" after every 3 parts. The holes for the dowels should serve the purpose sufficiently.
I may design the top and bottom parts that would be required for a proper turbine, but I want to investigate the profile in OpenFoam first. That may take a while, or never happen. If someone needs these parts, just say so and I will just make them with the current design.
EDIT: Top and bottom parts added. The .zip includes 5 extra pieces that need to be printed to have the top and bottom blades in a plane. I would suggest making a round plate for the top and the bottom.<

title: Samsung Galaxy S5 Qi Charging Stand (Work in Progress)

description.text:
Edit 10/1/14: I've added a bottom and legs to the design. In an attempt to make it easier to print, I've cut some angled holes and made tabs that you can glue in place to hold some bolts or pins to pivot on. I'm using a PowerBot PB1020 Qi wireless charging pad, and one of the samsung usb charging cables that I've had for a while. It should be recessed enough to let the Qi charging pad sit flush with the back, and still close enough to charge properly.
I'm still working out which sort of mechanism I'm going to use to actually prop it up, so this is just the main body of it for now. The actual stand mechanism will be added when I decide how I'm going to assemble it and how many asjustments I want it to have.

description.text:
Get the test print right first.
Print with a 1.5mm brim, more if you scale it up in size. Unlike my Chainmail #1, this version has very little footing area to stabilise the vertical donuts.
Try 0.2 to 0.35mm layer height and a good head fan, print slower and cooler until the spans bridge between the upright donuts correctly. Note that the donuts are formed by rotating a squished 12 sided polygon to improve the hole space utilisation inside the horizontal donuts.
If you have a fancy metal printer then do the big one, please print the "made by fluidity tag" and find an architectural use for it! :-) Post a picture too... it makes this place more interesting!
Cura slices the big print in about 15 seconds on my laptop.
I suspect it recognizes repeated elements.
You may have up to half a day slicing if you use slic3r with the big mesh
I've deliberately set a low polygon count to reduce the file size and to get a good start to printing the feet of the donuts, but there's a lot of surface area to process in a mesh like this!
Note that this mesh is much more flexible than my first version with the built in supports, I've programmed in more empty space around the donut grabs. to allow for expansion and contraction of the mesh.

Bowden adapter exclusive for the BCN3D+ printer with the BCNozzle 0,4 and 3mm diameter filament.
Complete BOM:
  • 1x PLA ST (0.2 layer) printed Bowden support.
  • 2x ABS HQ (0.1 layer) printed Bowden coupling. Note that there's a 1/8" threat inside.
  • 2x Pneufit straight adaptor,1/8inx6mm @ http://reprapworld.com/.
  • 0,7 meter of PTFE tubing, 3.18inner/6outer diameter @ http://reprapworld.com/.
  • Required fasteners (6x DIN912 M3x12, 4x DIN912 M5x16, 6x DIN934 M3 nuts, 4x DIN125 M5).
    UPDATE 1: after several tests, the best results were achieved with Cura. You will find the config files attached, for both PLA and ABS.
    See instructions for more info.
    UPDATE 2: New carriage design thanks to the great work of DaniSaez Remixed by me (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:428226)
    UPDATE 3: As ronald_kubo pointed at comments, this version is valid only for everybody who has a BCN3D+ starting with serial number 00.xxx (bought before November 2014). For those who has a BCN3D+ starting with serial number 01.xxx (bought after November 2014) use this remix.

The aim for this adapter was to improve the final quality of my printings. I detected some superficial waves due to inertia vibrations. After that improvement, the waves seems to be gone (Still working...)
The Bowden coupling needs to be printed in ABS with a layer height near to 0.1 because there is a 1/8 inch thread inside in order to couple the Pneufit adapter correctly.
This assembly, reutilize the original BCN3D+ extruder body (cold end) with the Bowden support part provided in order to facilitate the quick change between Bowden & standard extruder in case you dislike the way it works.
The best results were achieved using Cura as slicer.

title: FlashForge Dreamer Long Filament Spool Holder

description.text:
This is a replacement spool holder attachment for the FlashForge Dreamer printer. It allows you to use 3D printer filament spools that are wider, giving you more options for using spools inside the printer. The new spool holder is 8 mm longer than the original. The spool rod is the same diameter as the original. The handle and spool stop end are also the same diameter as the original, but with an improved handle. The handle length is also the same. Only the spool rod is extended. When inside the Dreamer the new spool holder has 1.5-2 mm of spaced between it's handle and the build plate. It's about as long as it can be. With this new spool holder I can now use the following brands of filament inside the Dreamer (they didn't fit using the original spool holder):

  • MG Chemicals 0.25 kg spools (58 mm wide)

  • Filamex 0.5 kg spools (56 mm wide)
    • I like having the filament rolls inside the printer because it keeps dust off of the filament and it feeds better. I designed this model from scratch using the popular free Blender 3D CAD software. It's great for this kind of 3D modeling. This thing was exported to an STL file using Blender as well. I highly recommend learning how to use Blender to design 3D objects for printing. It's free and very powerful, and directly supports importing and exporting STL files. As requested, I added the Blender source file for this object.

For best results use FlashForge White ABS printed at 230 C on the FlashForge Dreamer. It's strong ABS and came free with my printer. 230 C is recommended. Any lower and the ABS might not stick well to the build platform, and the part will also be more likely to break in use. Print the model standing upright to get smooth sides. Use support and a raft. Print at 90 mm/s if using Medium quality. Use at least 20% infill for strength. Use 3 shells. Use a heated bed at 105 C and TURN OFF THE FAN. It's very important to turn off the fan. That will help keep the ABS on the build plate and make the part stronger. I printed it on Kapton tape and it came out nicely. Blue Painter's tape is also recommended if you have trouble getting prints to stick on Kapton tape.

remixed_from.title: tracklib: OpenSCAD library for rendering toy train parts

title: Parametric T intersection track compatible with standard wooden train track

description.text:
Parametric module to create a T-shaped intersection piece of track for Thomas- and Brio-compatible wooden train sets. Parameters allow for changing between the two standard sizes for this shape of track, as well as control over the types of connectors at each end of the track.
 
To render this shape, you will need tracklib.scad installed in the same directory as this file, or the dotscad/trains repository cloned in its entirety (which will include this file and tracklib.scad).
 
This OpenSCAD library is part of the dotscad project, an open collection of modules and Things for 3d printing. Please check there for the latest versions of this and other related files.

comments.text: Can you provide a little more information on how to size this properly? I downloaded OpenSCAD and can render in OpenSCAD this part with different combinations of male and female connectors, but when I open the STL file in MakerBot, it says the part is too big for the printer and I have to scale it down to fit, which still looks like it's going to be too large once it's printed. Many thanks.
comments.author: Noreaster76

comments.text: Interesting, they should just print as-is.  However, the size scaling of these parts are based on the actual wooden track pieces you can buy, which means that even the "small" size will be over 21cm at its widest point.  If you size them down to fit a small printer, then they won't connect to any actual wooden track.
comments.author: Noreaster76

author: ex-nerd

description.text: For me, the original was choking Slic3r even after running it through Netfabb, so I simplified the mesh with Meshlab.  123k faces reduced to 86k, with a much smaller file.

title: Google Cardboard Magnetic Switch for OpenDive.

description.text: This will let you use the Google Cardboard app with a Dive headset. Tested with the Durovis Dive and the Color-Cross/NEJE Headsets In my opinion the Color-Cross is much, much better than the Durovis provided you don’t have a very big nose. It should work with other OpenDive type headsets. I only tested it with the LG-G3, some phones do not have sufficiently sensitive magnetometers to work with the Cardboard app. Unlike the paper Cardboard hardware with this you can fine tune the magnet placement.

Uses the same magnets needed for Cardboard as specified by Google: One neodymium ring magnet, and one ceramic disk magnet. Approximate size: 0.75in (19mm) diameter and 0.12in (3mm) thickness. Put a dab of superglue on the ceramic magnet and place it in the hole in the bottom half. Then superglue the top half on. Once it is fully dry (the magnets are quite strong, so wait a bit) put the neodymium ring magnet in the slot. I used a thin strip of black, Adhesive Putty to stick it to the side of the headset so it can be removed but Blu-Tack would probably be strong enough also.

comments.text: Thanks for this. It was a little small for my magnet so I enlarged it about 10%. Even at original size though the inside part wouldn't fit cleanly. I wound up supergluing the magnet inside and letting just using the outside track. Will see if it works after the glue sets!

description.text: Bowl honeycomb 2
This clip will snap onto the EL wire sold by adafruit.com.  I used 30 of these and the "EL starter pack" from Adafruit (19.95 USD) to light up my bike helmet.

Print 30 or so of these, and get some double-sided tape.  Light up your stuff, and dream of Tron!  
For my helmet design, I laid out the EL wire using masking tape.  The 2.5 meters in the starter pack was the perfect length (you can cut the EL wire. Just put the little cap back on when you're done).  I applied the clips to one side of the helmet, removing the tape as I went.  Then I made the other side symmetrical.  The inverting power supply takes two AAs, and clips to the back of the neck of my shirt.  The unit has three modes: two flash frequencies, and steady-on.

description.text: Advanced handy and practical stand for Sony NEX-7 (Alpha) tightened foot of Manfroto
This is a spacer for the MK4/MK3 extruder. It prevents the bolts on the bottom of the z-stage from colliding with the bolts on the build platform.

Back the filament out of the heater module, then remove the extruder from the Makerbot. Unscrew the bolts holding the heater module to the main body of the extruder, and remove them. Place the spacer on top of the insulator retainer. Replace the bolts that you removed with 16mm ones, and reinstall the heater module.
A small version of the bottom fan holder. Last version here : https://github.com/hugokernel/OpenSCAD_Things/tree/master/Ultimaker/Fan%20Plate

Print the 2 parts with 60% infill minimum.
Assembling the parts and seal the ends by heating with the tip of a soldering iron.
Screw a 60mm fan, that's it !

author: NAfoote2

description.text: The mount for Prusa Mendel, designed for standard PSU. It's placed in left-back, but you can always swap design for another side.

Some computer PSUs are useful for Prusa Mendel, you must only make sure it has good 12V rail inside PSU. Single Rail 12V is best choice, not two seperated 12V rails.
Coolermaster has in most PSUs single rail 12V for example.
I use the CM Master GX 450W, which has 35A 12V rail. The PSU seems good tested, it can almost full 100% without blew up, and it's also good protected against overload - which means this PSU cannot blew up. It's also not expensive for quality PSU with high efficiency 80+.
Problem, This PSU has fixed cables. I have designed some parts to make my printer a bit nicer. The mount part is also designed to avoid blocking the Z-axis part when x-carriage is in Z-min.
You can use the mount for all standard PSU dimensions.
It's easy to mount it on the side of Mendel. It will fit on 2 rods. Of course there are some PSU mounts, but i like mine more and it holds PSU at better place. I have also made part for hiding PSU cables: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:40679
The mount part is made with Google Sketchup.

comments.text:
It is for default PC PSU dimensions. You can Google it easy. Depth: 14 cm / Width: 8,5 cm / Height: 15 cm.
6 1/4" is approx. 15,88 cm, i think.

description.text:
Fraemes are your interchangeable, swappable, personalizable 3D-printed wonder-case. Designed by amazing artists from all over the world, the multi-part design (a 3D-printable insert, which you can pop in and out, and a rubber bumper) allow you to update your look as often as you please.
If you haven’t already snagged your bumper or if you want more designs, you can get them on our website, here: http://www.fraemes.com/makerbot
Have any questions? Just want to say hello? Don’t be shy - drop us a line at [email protected]

Fraemes are easily printed on your MakerBot using the high quality options in Makerware (ideally, use 0.1mm layer height, 40% infill, and no raft). You can use your favorite filament of choice (Fraemes are a perfect match for the MakerBot glow in the dark and photochromatic filaments). We've included a single file for your MakerBot Replicator and two smaller files for your MakerBot Mini. If you have any other questions, contact us at [email protected]

author: Deweydecimal

description.text:
This is for spool mount.
You need this part to avoid filament bend problems when printing at high Z heights.

I have used the parts from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:30742, but there is problem with my improved Prusa Mendel with new frame vertex. Because i can print at higher Z height, the spool holder part blocks the filament at x-min and x-max side. Thus i designed a new part to keep the problems low. The filament bend now much less and there should no serious problems when printing at high Z height. The part is thick enough to hold the heavy filament spools.
Designed and build with Google Sketchup.

I won't get my Printer for quite some time, but I'm trying to get a start on modelling some things I've been wanting to make.
This is a modular Pachinko Ball lifter. It is designed to take 11mm pachinko balls from the bottom catch bin of a pachinko machine, up to the top feed bin. It can be made taller by adding more "middle sections".
The Catch tray / Bottom unit directs pachinko balls toward the auger.
As the auger spins, it forces the packinko balls against the internal rib of the feed tube. at the top, a flap directs the balls out of the feed tube. 7-28-14: Added screw together augers as an alternative to the interlocking augers. I think these will work better, as long as the plastic is flexible enough to let the top of each joint snap past the bottom.

Do you dislike long cables from standard PSU? Well, here is box to hide it from your eyes and make your printer a bit nicer.
And there is power switch too!

The box is approximately 70x160x89 mm big. Just enough to print it on normal Prusa Mendel. You cannot cut unneeded cables from the PSU because you will lose the warranty, if the PSU is just brand new. The easy solution is to make a cable box for it, so you wont see ugly large cables from the PSU. You must print top, bottom and three clamps for it. See the images how it goes.
Only some words: the photos has first version box. The STL files here are already improved and should now have less problems when putting top and bottom together. You drill 4 holes in top part with 8mm drill, but don't go too far (max 38mm deep) or you cannot close the box anymore. So you don't need very large screws.
If done, then drill it with 3mm. In bottom part, drill it with 2,5 mm.
Drill the clamps with 2,5 mm holes if you use screws (or 3mm hole if you use bolts), but in clamp parts in top and bottom parts, drill it with 3 mm.
Use 4 screws (20mm is large enough) to close top part on the bottom part. You may mount bottom part first on the rod of the printer. Then let it rest on the small box below. Solder first for the power-on switch. Try put the cables inside the bottom part.
See the photos how it goes well. Some PSU has large cables, so my Coolermaster PSU cables will just fit inside. Don't forget the small hole at the side. It's for 12V cable to the printer. You can use it together with my PSU mount on http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:40672 It's designed with Google Sketchup.
Good luck!

remixed_from.author: mstolt
remixed_from.title: New z-Motor-Holder for the Velleman K8200 or 3Drag

description.text:
This is a double z-axis modification for the K8200 or 3Drag printer to eliminate the wobbling once for all.
It's based on two TR16x4 trapezoid spindles - which make it very solid but also stable and precise.

description.header: Parts you'll need to make this (see references for my sources of supply):
description.text:
• 2x right-handed TR16x4 trapezoid spindles 400mm length, ready to build-in [1]
  • 2x right-handed spindle nuts for TR16x4 [2]
  • 3x ball bearings 6200 (10x30x9) [3]
  • 1x flexible shaft coupling 5mm to 10 mm [4]
  • 1x tooth belt T5 10mm x 1215mm [5]
  • 2 pulleys T5, 20 teeth [6]
  • 1x snap-ring 10mm [7]
  • some screws (you can recycle some of the old z-axis screws)

    Instructions:

  • The pulleys are sold undrilled. You will need to do this yourself. Use a drill press or lathe for this. Drill diameter: 10mm in the lower half; 8mm in the upper half.
  • You should also add a set screw to fix the pulleys.
  • To be absolutely sure the pulleys won't slip off, you can drill a 3.3 mm hole in the top of the spindle, cut a thread for 4mm screws and fix the pulley with a screw as shown in the images.
  • The right spindle is secured by a snap-ring at its bottom (wear eye-protection when you mount the snap-ring!)
  • Since the spindle will be a little bit more away from the printer frame, you will need a new z-motor holder (Z-motor_mount.stl and Z-motor_panel.stl). I'm using a micrometer device to adjust the z-height. If you want this too, you need to print the parts micrometer_mount.stl and Z-switch_mount.stl
  • The original spool holder cannot be used anymore. I've made an alternative spool holder which can be used instead (spool_holder.stl)
  • The new z-resolution must be configured in Repetier Host: 3200 / 4 = 800 steps per mm (see screen shot).

    Notes:

  • The right ball bearing holder needs to be printed twice.
  • It's ok if the tooth belt is not very tautly. If you however think it is too floppy, you can stretch it with washers on the right ball bearing holders.
  • This modification reduces the z-resolution by the factor 4. However this is still good enough (800 steps per 1 mm height => 0.00125 mm per step) and furthermore all typical layer heights (0.1, 0.15, 0.20, etc.) are possible without any rounding errors.
  • The design files are included and can be opened with DesignSpark Mechanical - feel free to modify this thing at will...

    References:

description.text:
Test objects for compatibility with LEGO(r) Technic axles and '+' shaped axle-holes.
There are several holes with slightly different inside dimensions, so you can measure very precisely how your 3D printer handles the critical dimensions.

Print these out on your 3D printer. Try inserting '+' shaped axles into the various '+' shaped holes. Some holes will not fit at all and others will be too loose. It depends on the precise details of how your 3D printer deals with inside dimensions of holes. Use the results of your experiment to calibrate SCAD files that you use to create other objects.
One has holes aligned with the X axis, the others are rotated to a 20 degree angle; also one has thicker edges all the way around. Depending on your 3D printer, one will be better than the others. Full instructions and further explanation are in the block comment of "xhole-test.scad".
For more accurate measurement, you can use the tapered axle test object "axle-test.scad" ( thingiverse.com/thing:40594 )

This Spool holder is designed to slide onto the back of your MakerBot Replicator Mini and allow you to print with a MakerBot Large Spool of filament.
There are two versions of the bracket. One is designed to be printed on a larger printer if you have access to one, such as a Replicator 2. The other is compact enough to allow it to be printed on a Replicator Mini.
The tolerances on the Bracket to Spool Center are designed to be printed with PLA but should be fine in ABS as well.
To form a complete set you will need 1 bracket of your choice, 1 Spool Center, 1 Filament Tube Holder, 1 Bracket Pin and 1 Spool Pin. Thanks to KennySpade for testing the sizing for the Replicator Mini+ and providing the STL/OpenSCAD file for the bracket with updated sizing.

The Brackets and the Spool Center were printed with 2 shells, 25% fill and 0.3mm layer height.
The Pins were printed with 2 shells, 75% fill and 0.2mm layer height.
The Filament Tube Holder was printed with 2 shells, 15% fill and 0.3mm layer height.
Support should not be required for any of these, there is break away supports designed into the brackets already in order to allow easy cleaning.
The short bracket is designed to be printed flat on the Mini's build plate on a 45 degree angle going from corner to corner. It is a tight fit on the platform but it does fit.

description.text: Credit has to go to Plasma2002 for this one.  I simply took his idea and modified it to fit more common razor blades.  I also am including the AutoCad dwg file.  I made mine out of 1/4 inch acrylic and I love these things.  Gone is my honeycomb table.  No more is the occasional discoloration you get when the laser gets to the edge of the honeycomb table and is just a little too hot and melts the material you are working with.  Plus you can see so much better what you are working on.  I usually have around 6 of these little guys floating around on the bed at any given time or less if the material is smaller and I need to see around.

Simply laser cut these out on your laser cutter.  I am using a Full Spectrum 40W hobby laser 4th generation.  I use 25% speed 100% power to cut these little guys out.  I will say this I WOULD NOT USE THIS IN A PRODUCTION ENVIRONMENT WHERE I WAS NOT THE ONLY PERSON USING THE LASER.  I REPEAT DO NOT USE THESE AROUND CHILDREN OR PEOPLE WHO LACK THE INTELLIGENCE TO WORK WITH RAZOR BLADES FACING YOU.  They can be dangerous but so can your laser so if you can't work with razor blades you probably should bot be running a laser in the first place.  So I am sure all of you can handle it right?  With that said the advantage of using these far out way the danger if you can deal with that warning.  Give them a try my guess is you wont go back to your honeycomb table I know I won't.  Thank you Plasma2002 I know you have gotten a lot of flack over these guys but you made a believer out of me.

title: box with lid for deck of cards

description.text:
This box was designed to hold the numerous cards from "Munchkin Quest".
NOTICE: To save some material and reduce printing time, the bottom of the box and the lid are not completely filled. This means there are holes in it.

Printed with:
Prusa Mendel
ABS
Nozzle: 0.5 mm @ 220Â°C
Carrier: glass coated with ABS-aceton-solvent @ 120Â°C Advice for Skeinforge:
I tried the lower part of the box twice because the toothed belt jumped.
The reason for this fault is based on the thin walls of the lower part of the box.
As I tried printing this part with only 1 shell and used rectangular filling of the narrow walls, the rapid movement of the printer's head caused the toothed belt to slip.
To circumvent this problem:
Use 1 extra shell during printing. With this option the narrow walls will consist of 4 parallel lines and the printer's head moves smooth. I played a little with different wall thickness:
In my first design the wall was only 1 shell thick causing massive deformation of the walls during cooldown. Due to this deformation, some horizontal layers broke apart.

author: discovercamp1

description.text:
A cube, with speakers on 5 faces.
Can you hear me now?
The picture shows a small LM741 amplifier circuit to power the speakers. You can use any of a number of ways to power the speakers.

If you've got the speakers (36mm dia x 1.75mm mount height) that I've got, then just print, snap in the speakers, wire them up to something and play. Otherwise, tweak the openscad for your speaker as per http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:40689 (the speaker mount object that this is derived from). Amplifier: G Wellwood - Cutcher LM741 Amplifier - http://www.gwellwood.com/electronics/electronics-level-2/

UPDATE
While I had great result printing my own files, others unfortunately didn't and thus I will go back and change the male part to guarantee an easy fit.
You may have to print the male part slightly smaller (includes all current versions) in order to make the parts fit together. Old Description
This stand should work with all kinds of smartphones and up to 10'' tablets. I tested it with a Galaxy S3, iPhone 4s, iPad Air and iPad Mini.
It is adjustable in steps of 30° (Pi/6 if you use radians).
If you have a really thick tablet or a thick smartphone with case you might want to consider using the version with the larger hook.
Important & Change Log:

I replaced the two male files with one:
V3_1Male includes a resized gear (male part) at 96% of the previous version so both parts fit together easily.
In case you downloaded the V3 male part (This does not apply to the female part):
"If you fit the gear into the counterpart for the first time, start by pushing it in a little and pull it out gentally, then push it in a little more and repeat. This prevents breaking the parts.
I printed the stand at 95% scale, both parts seperatly."
Recomended settings:

Recommendations
Material: PLA
Temp: Will vary, but I used 195 for the first layer and 195 for the rest
Layer height: 0.2mm, but 0.3 should also work
Perimeters: 3
Top & Bottom Layers: 3
Infill: 30% or more
Brim: at least 4 perimeters
Support: No
Units are in mm (of the file).

comments.text: UPDATE: Yup, 95% on the female made it fit for me, not a lot holding it in now but not going to fall out either. You could probably play with it at 96-98 to get it snug but moveable.

comments.text: I liked the design of this stand. Works for both my cell phone and 8" inch tablet. I'm using a Davinci 1.0 printer and the default STL didn't work. I ended up having to size them differently to get it to fit. I did a few prints to get it right and I scaled the female end to 105% and the male end to 95%. This seemed to work good. This made a tight fit, but allowed me to get the parts working. I used .2 resolution and 40% infill.

Kunai Throwing Spike modeled in solidworks.

A few minor accessories for the Rigidbot 3-d Printer.
Consists of:
2 Top Caps - To fill in square holes on top side of printer opposite the spool holder
2 Spool Holder Top Caps - To fill in square holes on top of the spool rack.
1 Allen Wrench holder - Clips on any square rail and is sized to fit the three allen wrenches supplied with the rigidtbot, as well as one for tightening the drive belts. (put a revised allen wrench holder inside as well with 45 degree overhangs to print without supports)
2 Replacement Rod Holders for the spool holder - One is made to remain bolted to the frame and have a looser fit on the rod to allow the rod to be easily pulled free. The second is made with a wrap around clip and no bolt holes to allow it to easily be removed and replaced while removing or changing the filament spools. The clipped rod holder has a tight fit on the rod and a longer tapered "nose" to allow it to be inserted more easily.

remixed_from.title: Spring loaded extruder mod for Creatr dual exstruder -V5 final version

title: Stabilising 12 mm top rail with 12 mm bearings for spring loaded Creatr exstruder -V6 final

description.text:
After seeing how much the original setup vibrates during printing.
I made a version of this for my Spring loaded exstruder.
Its made a big difference on the quality of the prints, i no longer get a seam on small sylinders and items generally come out much much smoother.
There are now 2 versions of this, one with the cables coming in in front and one that is structured to receive the cable feed in the back.

THis only works together with the spring loaded ekstruder, you have to download the side holders from extra Bendit-ed 12 mm guide rod for leapfrog creatr.
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:209408

comments.text: Is it possible to also provide the parts which go on the side rails?
comments.author: Outbound
